thread.title: Celebrate autumn's bounty at local festivals
thread.title_full: Celebrate autumn's bounty at local festivals

title: Celebrate autumn's bounty at local festivals
text:
Celebrate autumn's bounty at local festivals Michelle Almonte , malmonte@lohud.com 12:49 p.m. EDT October 9, 2015 Buy Photo Celebrate all things fall at Greenburgh Nature Center's annual festival. (Photo: Tabitha Pearson Marshall for the Journal News) Buy Photo 92 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Colorful leaves, cozy sweaters and pumpkin lattes are just a few of our favorite fall things. In addition to the crisper air and shorter days, the season also brings a bounty of fun-filled, harvest festivals celebrating all things autumn. 
Greenburgh Nature Center Fall Festival 
On Sunday, kids of all ages can spend an afternoon building scarecrows, meeting animals, painting and enjoying a bounty of fall activities including pumpkin carving, cider making, tractor rides and scavenger hunts. The festival is a precursor to the nature center’s Scarecrow and Pumpkin Parade on Oct. 25. Scarecrows crafted at the festival are left on the grounds and used in the procession. Advance admission (if registered online by Oct. 10): $10; day of event: $15; children under 2, free. $5 per pumpkin, $2 per scarecrow. Event held rain or shine. No refunds. 11 a.m.-3 p.m. Visit www.greenburghnaturecenter.org for parade details and other information. Greenburgh Nature Center, 99 Dromore Road, Scarsdale. 
Fall Festival at Edith G. Read Wildlife Sanctuary 
Nature lovers unite and head over to Edith G. Read Wildlife Sanctuary’s for its annual Fall Festival. The fun-filled day features birds of prey demonstration, live animals presentations, storytelling, pumpkin patch, live music and food. Noon-5 p.m. Oct. 17. Read Wildlife Sanctuary, 1 Playland Parkway, adjacent to the amusement park. 914-967-8720. Friendsofreadwildlifesanctuary.org 
Calendar: Events.lohud.com 
Nyack Street Fair 
The quintessential outdoor festival shuts down most of downtown Nyack, transforming the village into an outdoor mecca for those of all ages. There are over 300 booths featuring arts, crafts, retail items, commercial booths, collectibles and festival foods. A large children's area will be set up in the Main Street parking lot with rides and games. Rain or shine. 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday. www.pjspromotions.com 
Pound Ridge Harvest Festival 
This year’s festival mark’s the event’s fifth anniversary and features a headlining performance by 90's alternative rock band Soul Asylum. The Grammy-winning group, best known for hits such as "Runaway Train" and "Misery" , will appear on Oct. 17 at the festival’s new location, Pound Ridge Town Park. A celebration of local food and culture, the festival offers something for everyone from wine tastings, craft beers, and dishes by local merchants and specialty food purveyors to face painting, contests and games for the kids at a root beer garden. The day of music, family-fun, food and drink will also feature performances by Fox Lane Rock Ensemble, a band comprised of eighth graders from the local middle school. Admission is free, but special VIP tickets are available for $150 and include a special meet-and-greet with Soul Asylum, access to a preferred viewing area, a limited edition signed poster, festival commemorative goodies and priority access to beer and wine lines. 1-6 p.m. Rain date Oct. 18. 179 Westchester Ave., Pound Ridge. Poundridgeharvestfestival.com 
Soul Asylum with Dave Pirner, center. (Photo: Red Light Management, Red Light Management) 
lohud Wine Crush 
Raise your glass in celebration of autumn’s bounty at the lohud Wine Crush on Oct. 12. The free, family-friendly event at Harvest on Hudson features more than 25 local farmers market vendors, live music, cooking demonstrations and more. Join food writer Megan McCaffrey to stomp some grapes and then raise a glass to the region’s peak season. Chef David Amorelli will lead cooking demonstrations, and local taste-makers such as Yonkers Brewery, Pie Lady & Son, Hudson Distillery, Penny Lick Ice Cream, Honey Locust Farm House and Fazio Farms will be on hand selling and sampling goods. Noon-4 p.m. Harvest on Hudson, 1 River St., Hastings-on-Hudson, 914-478-2800. www.harvesthudson.com Buy Photo 
Gather at Harvest on Hudson in Hastings for lohud Wine Crush on Oct. 12. (Photo: Ricky Flores/The Journal News) 
Westchester's Ridge Hill’s Harvestfest 
Trick-or-treaters can get a jump start on Halloween at Harvestfest . Children are encouraged to come in costume and trick or treat at the various participating stores and restaurants throughout the shopping center. The activity-rich day offers something for both young and old. Pumpkin decorating, pony rides, arts and crafts, demonstrations and a petting zoo keep the little ones entertained–while adults can learn some new moves during a square dancing session with Live bluegrass and satisfy food and drink cravings with seasonal dishes from local eateries and beer tastings from the Broken Bow brewery. Free admission. Noon-4 p.m. Oct. 24. 1 Ridge Hill Boulevard, Yonkers. 914-207-2900. Westchestersridgehill.com 
Fall in Love at the Farm 
Though technically not a festival, the variety of activities offered at Hilltop Hanover’s Fall in Love at the Farm program are consistent with–and–just as fun as–those at your typical harvest celebration. Offered Saturdays throughout the month (10 a.m. – 4 p.m.), the program features free tours of the farm, face painting and crafts, pumpkin picking and hot cider. On Halloween, return to the farm donning your spookiest costume and receive 10 percent off produce purchases, meet Zombie farmers, pick pumpkins, enjoy cider, farm tours and crafts and try your hand at cow-pie bingo. Additional dates include: Oct. 17, 24 and 31. Hilltop Hanover Farm and Environmental Center, 1271 Hanover St., Yorktown Heights. hilltophanoverfarm.org 
For more, go to events.lohud.com . 92 CONNECT 6 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://lohud.us/1LjM908 More Stories
